description:
The verb is from Middle English crien (13th century), from Old French crier (“to announce publicly, proclaim, scream, shout”) (whence Medieval Latin crīdō (“to cry out, shout, publish, proclaim”)).
The noun is from Middle English crie, from Old French cri, crïee.

The origin of the Old French (and Middle Latin) word is uncertain, if Germanic, it is from Frankish *krītan (“to cry, cry out, publish”), from Proto-Germanic *krītaną (“to cry out, shout”), from Proto-Indo-European *greyd- (“to shout”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian kriete (“to cry”), Dutch krijten (“to cry”) and krijsen (“to shriek”), German Low German krieten (“to cry, call out, shriek”), German kreißen (“to cry loudly, wail, groan”), Gothic 𐌺𐍂𐌴𐌹𐍄𐌰𐌽 (kreitan, “to cry, scream, call out”), further Indo-European cognates: Latin gingrītus (“the cackling of geese”), Middle Irish grith (“a cry”), Welsh gryd (“a scream”), Persian گریه‎ (gerye, “to cry”), Sanskrit क्रन्दन (krandana, “cry, lamentation”).

An alternate etymology connects the Medieval Latin word to  quiritō (“to wail, shriek”). This is itself of uncertain origin, perhaps from  Latin queror (“to complain”) through the form, though the phonetic and semantic developments are difficult to trace; alternatively,  a variant of quirritare (“to squeal like a pig”), from *quis, an onomatopoeic rendition of squeaking. An ancient folk etymology understood it as  "to call for the help of the Quirites," the Roman constabulary.

entries.meaning: A shedding of tears; the act of crying.
examples: After we broke up, I retreated to my room for a good cry.
I heard a cry from afar.

[…]  Before the gates there sat / On either side a formidable shape; / The one seem’d woman to the waste, and fair, / But ended foul in many a scaly fold / Voluminous and vast, a serpent arm’d / With mortal sting: about her middle round / A cry of hell-hounds never ceasing bark’d / With wide Cerberean mouths full loud and rung / A hideous peal; yet, when they list,would creep, / If ought disturb'd their noise, into her womb, / and kennel there, yet there still bark’d and howl’d, / Within unseen.  […]

entries.meaning: (by extension, obsolete, derogatory) A pack or company of people.
(of an animal) A typical sound made by the species in question.
examples: "Woof" is the cry of a dog, while "neigh" is the cry of a horse.

verbs.description: cry (third-person singular simple present cries, present participle crying, simple past and past participle cried)

examples: That sad movie always makes me cry.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter loudly; to call out; to declare publicly.
(intransitive) To utter inarticulate sounds, as animals do.
(transitive) To cause to do something, or bring to some state, by crying or weeping.
examples: Tonight I’ll cry myself to sleep.

entries.meaning: To make oral and public proclamation of; to notify or advertise by outcry, especially things lost or found, goods to be sold, auctioned, etc.
Hence, to publish the banns of, as for marriage.
examples: I should not be surprised if they were cried in church next Sabbath.
